H0.text: Deep roots are the characteristic that will best prevent a tree from being blown over by high winds during a storm.

H1.text: Long branches are the characteristic that best prevents a tree from being blown over by high winds during a storm.

H2.text: Thick bark is the characteristic that best prevents a tree from being blown over by high winds during a storm.

H3.text: Wide leaves will best prevent a tree from being blown over by high winds during a storm.

A4.text: Roots fix the plant in the substrate and resist mechanical forces (wind, waterflow); vigorous root systems are essential for crop stability and prevention of lodging.

A5.text: Tree roots usually grow to three times the diameter of the branch spread, only half of which lie underneath the trunk and canopy.
